qas.question: Where is the Semetic Akkadian language first found?

answers.text: proper names of the kings of Kish

qas.question: Where is the Semetic Akkadian language found preserved after 2800 BC?
During whose rule was the use of Old Akkadian at its peak?
What language did scribes use over Akkadian?
How long did Akkadian and Sumerian coexist as spoken languages?
What language was used only to make the king lists?
What language was used for the kings list in the 28th century BC?

plausible_answers.text: texts written entirely in Old Akkadian

qas.question: What was written in the 25th century BC?
Who's reign ended in the 22nd century BC?
What was a literary language by the 18th century BC?

context: The <b5_0>Semitic <b6_0>Akkadian language<b6_0/><b5_0/> is first attested in <a0_0>proper names of the kings of Kish<a0_0/> c. 2800 BC, preserved in later <a1_0>king lists<a1_0/>. There are <b7_0>texts written entirely in Old Akkadian<b7_0/> dating from c. 2500 BC. Use of Old Akkadian was at its peak during the rule of <a2_0><b8_0>Sargon the Great<b8_0/><a2_0/> (c. 2270–2215 BC), but even then most administrative tablets continued to be written in <a3_0>Sumerian<a3_0/>, the language used by the scribes. Gelb and Westenholz differentiate three stages of Old Akkadian: that of the pre-Sargonic era, that of the Akkadian empire, and that of the "Neo-Sumerian Renaissance" that followed it. Akkadian and Sumerian coexisted as vernacular languages for <a4_0>about one thousand years<a4_0/>, but by around 1800 BC, <b9_0>Sumerian<b9_0/> was becoming more of a literary language familiar mainly only to scholars and scribes. Thorkild Jacobsen has argued that there is little break in historical continuity between the pre- and post-Sargon periods, and that too much emphasis has been placed on the perception of a "Semitic vs. Sumerian" conflict. However, it is certain that Akkadian was also briefly imposed on neighboring parts of Elam that were previously conquered by Sargon.
